_data.description: Hi, I'm Prashant Shrestha, a web developer currently studying in Japan. I've worked with various languages and frameworks; But I still consider myself a code-ok. Recently, I've been working a lot with Vue.js, Nuxt.js, Firebase and TypeScript
_data.title: An introduction
_data.subtitle: Hi, my name is Prashant. I'm a codeok.
_data.lead: Where I finally decided to blog

children.value: , currently a student at Tokyo Institute of Technology in Japan.

I've worked with various languages and frameworks. Recently, I've been working a lot with Vue.js, Nuxt.js, Firebase and TypeScript. However, I still consider myself a code-ok. In fact, I love coding not for the sake of coding itself but for the creativity and automation it provides me to build stuffs. Therefore, I am ok with being a code-ok lol. Not that great, nor that bad, just ok, that's code-ok!!
I've always liked the idea of having a blog where I can share my thoughts, stories, and ideas. A way to share and flex my expertise and, at the same time, learn and improve my shortcomings.

I'll be sharing my experiences as a student in Japan. I'll also be sharing my experiences on other topics such as web development or machine learning or anything I get to work on that I think people might find interesting in the realm of building with code. I believe anyone can become a code-ok, the tough part as well as the exciting one is where you build stuff with code and bring your ideas to life.
And if you're interested in my github page,
! However it is empty atm but I will soon be adding more.

_data.text:
Hi, I'm **Prashant Shrestha**, currently a student at Tokyo Institute of Technology in Japan. 

I've worked with various languages and frameworks. Recently, I've been working a lot with Vue.js, Nuxt.js, Firebase and TypeScript. However, I still consider myself a code-ok. In fact, I love coding not for the sake of coding itself but for the creativity and automation it provides me to build stuffs. Therefore, I am ok with being a code-ok lol. Not that great, nor that bad, just ok, that's code-ok!!

I've always liked the idea of having a blog where I can share my thoughts, stories, and ideas. A way to share and flex my expertise and, at the same time, learn and improve my shortcomings.

I'll be sharing my experiences as a student in Japan. I'll also be sharing my experiences on other topics such as web development or machine learning or anything I get to work on that I think people might find interesting in the realm of building with code. I believe anyone can become a code-ok, the tough part as well as the exciting one is where you build stuff with code and bring your ideas to life.

And if you're interested in my github page, [Here it is](https://github.com/Arsen8848)! However it is empty atm but I will soon be adding more.

Stay tuned!

_data.description: How to resize and optimize images before uploading them to Cloud Storage using Canvas API
_data.title: Resizing and Optimizing Images Using Canvas API
_data.subtitle: How to resize and optimize images before uploading them to Cloud Storage using Canvas API
_data.lead: The Canvas API provides a means, among other things, to manipulate photos, which is perfect for resizing and optimizing images before uploading them to Cloud Firestore.

cover.alt: Optimizing and Resizing Images Using Canvas API cover image
cover.caption: Photo by Tranmautritam from Pexels

children.value: In web development, resizing is a common practice done before uploading any image to a cloud storage. In addition to saving space, reducing the image size before uploading ensures that the image will be the same size across all web browsers. Not all web browsers render HTML in quite the same way, so resizing on the browser side can lead to images not displaying correctly. Therefore, it's also a safe practice to resize images before uploading them. In this article, we shall look into how to resize and optimize an image before uploading it.
provides a means for drawing graphics via
element. Among other things, it can be used for animation, game graphics, data visualization, photo manipulation, and real-time video processing.
Going through the documentation, it looks like the Canvas API is ideal for manipulating images on the browser. Since our goal is to
an image, the basic steps we need are:

The file element is one of those things that's a bit troublesome to style and in most cases you'd find it more practical to just hide it completely. The common technique is to simply hide the file input element and have another element trigger a
event on the file input element.
The snippet below demonstrates the use of this technique. In addition, a preview of the image is added to create a "compound" element, which enhances an otherwise plain file input element.
for the effects of the CSS classes used.
<!-- Clicking this button triggers the "click" event of the file input. -->
<!-- This is the real file input element which we are hiding -->

A blog site usually uses 2 images - a cover image and a thumbnail version of the cover. Rather than having to manually resize the images, it would be ideal to upload a single image and let the application create the thumbnail variation that has a smaller width (< 640px). In addition, it is also better to resize the original image to a more reasonable size of around 1280px width.
We need a template that does the following:
Create a resized optimized version of the original image to be used as the cover.
Create a resized optimized version of the original image to be used as the thumbnail.
Upload both versions to Firebase Cloud Firestore and store the download URLs in blog.
The snippet below demonstrates the use of this technique.
// Trigger the file input click event, which launches
// Upload the thumbnail with a slight change in the filename.
// Once both files have been uploaded, update the blog details.
// Create a reference to the destination where we're uploading
// Once the image is uploaded, obtain the download URL, which
// is the publicly accessible URL of the image.
// Create an image element that will store our optimized image.
// Once we have the resized image, further optimize it using
// This is where we actually resize the image using the
If you are using Firebase, you can choose to optimize the images using
performs the optimization on the server automatically whenever a new image is uploaded. There's even a
that you can immediately use without any coding. It is definitely worth checking out.
